this depends on the particular skills business types with no open source experience are often terrible when they are in a position of authority over open source developers the profit model is entirely different and apparently incomprehensible unless they ve either seen it up close or have very carefully studied e g cygnus and rhat business models

i spent a few years in the mid is working on the design of fault tolerant organizations hoping to create information exchange pathways inside organizations that limited the harm that could be done through the loss or failure of any individual the large scale experiment the scaleable company that we were building pretty much failed ended up being rebuilt form the ground up on a different basis using contractor labor in part because i had neither identified nor solved these problems and in part because we were working inside an existing organizational structure and not all the systems for necessary decentralization and elimination of single points of failure could be implemented as much as the article is text the image you chose to illustrate it speaks to the most interesting approach to this problem i have seen anyone take to date about years ago a good friend was running a nonprofit with a chronically dysfunctional board of directors he gained access to a big pulling boat or big oars on a lifeboat sized wooden hull i think it was a replica of one of the launches on capt vancouver is ship and he took the board out for a spin and steered them into serious currents way out in the bay and then disabled the rudder at which point they really had no choice other than a tow from the coast guard but to cooperate at a truly physical level to listen with their arms and backs and legs to one another is muscles on the other oars and coordinate their efforts if they were to get back to the harbor but whether or not a single experience like that can really change the way people deal with one another is another matter entirely
correct any weaknesses in one are compensated in another and vice versa

i spent a few years in the mid is working on the design of fault tolerant organizations hoping to create information exchange pathways inside organizations that limited the harm that could be done through the loss or failure of any individual the large scale experiment the scaleable company that we were building pretty much failed ended up being rebuilt form the ground up on a different basis using contractor labor in part because i had neither identified nor solved these problems and in part because we were working inside an existing organizational structure and not all the systems for necessary decentralization and elimination of single points of failure could be implemented as much as the article is text the image you chose to illustrate it speaks to the most interesting approach to this problem i have seen anyone take to date about years ago a good friend was running a nonprofit with a chronically dysfunctional board of directors he gained access to a big pulling boat or big oars on a lifeboat sized wooden hull i think it was a replica of one of the launches on capt vancouver is ship and he took the board out for a spin and steered them into serious currents way out in the bay and then disabled the rudder at which point they really had no choice other than a tow from the coast guard but to cooperate at a truly physical level to listen with their arms and backs and legs to one another is muscles on the other oars and coordinate their efforts if they were to get back to the harbor but whether or not a single experience like that can really change the way people deal with one another is another matter entirely
correct any weaknesses in one are compensated in another and vice versa
this is completely depend on determination and make the hay while sun shine
great advise

somebody is oar is not in the water i never rowed a cyl i believethat i would take alot of training to make this dragonfly move asone different skills are great but to move the water rocket above theybetter become one with the boat right now its hard for me tothink i miss my single shell very very much
interesting
different skills yet they are doing the same thing i think a more apt picture would have been a crane and construction crew

all_comments.text: martin ockovsky i am not sure what your point is if i am selling cell phones i am going to target countries where there are a lot of people never mind the total of the population with a cell phone a sale is a sale if i can sell a billion cell phones in china vs having million sales and dominating the slovakian market guess which one i am going to pick
nice

i never said that you are not bright and i did not mean it like that it is just whenever i see graphs like this i get annoyed oooo in china there is bilion phones what a great market never mind that more then million people still do not have any phone which is basically market the size of usa india the same so yeah there is shit load of sold phones in there but still huge and by huge i mean really huge chunk of market without any phone that is because those people are poor do you mean that based on this graph you can see business opportunity well good luck competing with cheap phones made in india and china i am from slovakia small country with population about million so we would need phones for every citizen to make that chart and i can notell you for a fact that there is more phones then citizens in slovakia so if you would take it by population phone ratio you would clearly get really different graph but it would not tell you anything either imho
well if you do not know that the bigger market you have the bigger chance you have to sell the product then good morning

largest countries by population china india us indonesia brazil pakistan nigeria bangladesh russia japan mexico philippines vietnam so i have to disagree bill gross especially since this is total number of cell phones and not internet enabled smartphones

shouldn t the interesting figure be how many percent of the population that has a cell phone i mean for one thing wikipedia tells me that the population of france upper end of the graph wih less cell phones is while the population of china lower end of the graph with more cell phones is

coupled with the almost unlimited computing power from the cloud available to smartphones through wireless connectivity the capability to see hear smell continuously will make our smartphones truly like a human companion lin zhong rice universitythe unequivocal trend is that more and more mobile phones will have access to the internet in the future the distriction between cell phone and smartphone will naturally blur as internet access will become a baseline feature for most any mobile phone

scott ramsay i just read that there is a unlocked smartphone in india it only has a screen but that is still amazing we ve a ways to go but the fact that the prices are falling so fast and the features going up so fast is great i think

erich feldmeier cell phones still need the ground based infrastructure most of the call is still traveling over landline it goes cellphone gt tower gt landline gt possibly satellite gt landline gt tower gt cellphone wireless communication is not all wireless
and what percentage are so called smartphones
bill gross what is your source for this data i would like to do some further study with this data

bill gross thanks i absolutely agree i am sure there actually is a lot of truth in what you said in your original post it d be good to see a complete set of figures which answer all the questions that each of the others might individually not be able to answer

it d also be useful to know the average cost of a cellphone in these countries if people in low gdp countries have access to cheap cheap phones then sure so what nothing really surprising there if they re buying galaxy ss and iphones we might have a case for using the word amazingly
erich feldmeier i guess i learned something new today

yeah of course but i was reacting to this amazingly if you look at the top countries by cell phones the list is dominated by many low gdp countries the list is not about the ratio of people owning phone it is based on the number of inhabitants so it is not surprising that countries with low gdp are dominating that list because they have the most inhabitants i really do not know what is hard to understand about that
the postal mail revolution is democratic the street address revolution is democratic the silverware revolution is democratic the frying pan revolution is democratic and so on
jason kalka thx of course but with lte you need not direct lines from communication partner to communication partner as before that seems a big advantage for countries with few people

and related to that fiona spears of course larger countries will have more cellphones if this is about the democracy of people choosing to spend their money on cellphones the figures need to be expressed as a percentage of the total people in those countries who ve parted with their cash

one small contributing factor is that the systems are so unstructured that things do not get through in these countries without a sustained barrage of followup phone calls a phone call in human voice still carries more weight than a traceable email in these parts of the world because an email costs almost nothing it is valued that much lesser just an interesting input to the trend
how was this calculated many of these countries have more cell phones than citizens
skipping technology from yesterday like cable infrastructure too expensive now in low developed countries of course
where is saudi arabia
what is the big deal isn t this basically correlated mostly to population
thank god for once we do not rate which is surprising

it is number of phones in countries not ratio between number of phones and number of inhabitants no shit that the countries which biggest amount of inhabitants have the biggest amount of phones this graph has no value what so ever

is it because in those countries they rely on mobile devices replacing the domestic internet access it is the cheapest form of information and communication access in those countries russia brazil india and china are the bric countries with a faster growing number of internet users china being already number also interesting to see would be the use of mobile phones for communication vs other tasks separated by g bric and other countries btw china india russia and brazil are in the top gdp countries

a mobile phone is not a smart phone per se
